pageData.text: In this investigation, students will perform a <button className='glossary-text'>transesterification</button> of vegetable oil in the presence of a solid <button className='glossary-text'>catalyst</button> to produce biodiesel. Students will test for the presence of contaminants such as soap to determine the purity of their sample.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 10 minutes 
Activity 1: Synthesis of Biodiesel – 60 minutes + 2 days 
Activity 2: Testing for Quality – 90 minutes

text: Describe the synthesis pathway for biodiesel.

pageData.text: Algae biofuel is obtained from a process that converts single-celled photosynthetic organisms (referred to as microalgae) into biodiesel. There are an enormous number of algae species (some estimates place the number over one million), and of these species, some can double their mass in as little as six hours, so the sources for this alternative fuel are vast. Algae is also responsible for more than 40% of global carbon fixation.<sup class = 'bodysuperscript'>1</sup> Carbon fixation refers to the transformation of atmospheric carbon into an organic compound. For this reason, scientists feel that algae can play a key role in reducing the volume of excess carbon dioxide in our atmosphere, which acts as a greenhouse gas by trapping heat in the atmosphere.

1Hannon, M., Gimpel, J., Tran, M., Rasala, B., & Mayfield, S. (2010, September). Biofuels from algae: Challenges and potential. Biofuels.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3152439/

pageData.desc: A cube of aerogel on display.
pageData.altText: A man in a lab coat holding up one of several flasks of algae growing in clear liquid.

pageData.text: Renewable sources of energy and fuel are becoming increasingly valuable. Unlike the most common form of diesel, which is distilled from petroleum, biodiesel can be produced from a variety of renewable sources. The adoption of alternative fuel sources, such as biodiesel, can help reduce our dependence on fossil fuels.

Biodiesel has several advantages over traditional petroleum diesel. It is cleaner burning, producing less particulate matter and less carbon monoxide. In post 2010 vehicles with modern emission control technologies, nitrogen oxides (NO<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>x</sub>) emissions are comparable to traditional diesel. Though biodiesel still releases carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, that carbon had to be recently sequestered into the tissues of the plants from which the oil was made, so there is no net increase of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. Biodiesel is biodegradable and non-toxic, and can be used in several ways. Diesel engines require no modifications in order to use it as a fuel, though engines that have run on petroleum diesel may experience clogged filters and pipes since biodiesel strips deposits left behind by other petroleum diesel. Biodiesel can also be used in place of heating oil in homes.

The biodiesel production process has surprisingly few steps. Generally, all that is required is a pure vegetable oil, a solid base like potassium hydroxide or calcium hydroxide, and methanol. Calcium hydroxide, for example, is mixed thoroughly with methanol to produce calcium methoxide. Vegetable oil is then added to the methoxide and mixed. The <button className='glossary-text'>triglycerides</button> in the oil react with the methoxide through a <button className='glossary-text'>transesterification</button> reaction to create methyl <button className='glossary-text'>esters</button> (biodiesel) and glycerol. The solution then separates into a layer of biodiesel and a layer of glycerol, which facilitates the easy collection of the biodiesel.

A transesterification reaction is the process of exchanging an organic ester group with an alcohol group between two molecules. An ester is typically represented as RCOOR1 where each R represents a carbon chain. The carbon has one oxygen bound to it with a double bond, one oxygen bound with a single bond, and a carbon from the carbon chain. In this reaction the alcohol group from the methanol will be exchanged with each of the ester groups on the triglyceride.
In practice, the synthesis of biodiesel is complicated by impurities in the oil, such as excess water, free , or other chemicals that may lead to side products in the reaction

The first step in the process of biodiesel production is choosing a stock of oil to work from. This can be derived from a variety of sources, including animal fats, or vegetable oils such as corn, canola, or soy. The oil can be produced from algae or can even be recovered from sewage or deep fryers. In general, an oil that has been previously used, such as in a deep fryer, has more contaminants that will need to be removed through filtration or other chemical processes, and the oil must be subjected to a drying process to remove excess water.

Another potential contaminant can arise in the oil itself, in the form of free fatty acids. These fatty acids can interfere with the transesterification reaction and generate soap instead of biodiesel.

pageData.question: Which of the following compounds are required to produce biodiesel?

options.text: pure oil, a solid base, methanol
used vegetable oil and a solid acid
animal fat, a solid base, ethanol
methyl esters, calcium carbonate, acetic acid

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Generally, all that is required is pure vegetable oil, a solid base like potassium hydroxide or calcium hydroxide, and methanol.

pageData.question: Which of the following are produced during the transesterification reaction during biodiesel production?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Methyl esters and glycerol are produced during the transesterification reaction during biodiesel production.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
The biodiesel production process has surprisingly few steps. Generally, all that is required is a pure vegetable oil, a solid base like potassium hydroxide or calcium hydroxide, and methanol. Calcium hydroxide, for example, is mixed thoroughly with methanol to produce calcium methoxide. Vegetable oil is then added to the methoxide and mixed. The triglycerides in the oil react with the methoxide through a transesterification reaction to create methyl esters (biodiesel) and glycerol. The solution then separates into a layer of biodiesel and a layer of glycerol, which facilitates the easy collection of the biodiesel.

A transesterification reaction is the process of exchanging an organic ester group with an alcohol group between two molecules. In this reaction the alcohol group from the methanol will be exchanged with each of the ester groups on the triglyceride.

hintData.body:
The biodiesel production process has surprisingly few steps. Generally, all that is required is a pure vegetable oil, a solid base like potassium hydroxide or calcium hydroxide, and methanol. Calcium hydroxide, for example, is mixed thoroughly with methanol to produce calcium methoxide. Vegetable oil is then added to the methoxide and mixed. The triglycerides in the oil react with the methoxide through a transesterification reaction to create methyl esters (biodiesel) and glycerol. The solution then separates into a layer of biodiesel and a layer of glycerol, which facilitates the easy collection of the biodiesel.

A transesterification reaction is the process of exchanging an organic ester group with an alcohol group between two molecules. In this reaction the alcohol group from the methanol will be exchanged with each of the ester groups on the triglyceride.

pageData.text: In this investigation, corn oil will be used for the creation of your biodiesel. Because the oil was not previously used, filtration will not be necessary before the synthesis.

The provided methanol is a required reagent for the <button className='glossary-text'>transesterification</button> reaction. The calcium hydroxide reacts with the methanol (CH<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>3</sub>OH) to yield calcium methoxide, Ca(OCH<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>3</sub>)<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>2</sub>, which acts as a <button className='glossary-text'>catalyst</button> for the subsequent reaction.

pageData.title: Detailed Synthesis
pageData.text: The first reaction in this activity is the synthesis of calcium methoxide. Calcium hydroxide is added to methanol where it reacts to form calcium methoxide (Figure 1). In the second reaction, the calcium methoxide acts as a catalyst, facilitating the transesterification of methanol with to produce glycerol and .

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Structural formula of synthesis of methoxide shown with structural models with calcium hydroxide reacting with methanol

pageData.title: Biodiesel Synthesis
pageData.text: First, the calcium methoxide reacts with the methanol, creating a negative dipole at an oxygen and a positive dipole at a hydrogen (Figure 2). This molecule will react in the last step of the process.

pageData.disc: Figure 2. Calcium methoxide and methanol reaction
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Structural formula of reaction of calcium methoxide catalyst with methanol to create intermediate molecule with structural formulas

pageData.text: A second calcium methoxide then reacts with a on a , with the calcium associating with the oxygen of the , and an oxygen of the calcium methoxide reacting with the carbon of the ester. This product is then used in the final step of the reaction (Figure 3).

pageData.desc: Figure 3. Calcium methoxide and triglyceride reaction
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Structural formula of a triglyceride reacting with calcium methoxide to form an ester intermediate

pageData.text: In the third step of the reaction, the step one product reacts with the step two product to form the methyl ester (biodiesel), a diglyceride, and regenerates the two molecules of calcium methoxide. The process then repeats until each fatty acid is used up and the end products are three methyl esters and a glycerol molecule .

pageData.question: In this investigation, corn oil will be used. Which of the following best explains why this oil does not need to be filtered before using it in biodiesel synthesis?

options.text: The oil was not previously used.
The oil will form an emulsion when mixed with water.
The oil has already been filtered.
The oil is a catalyst and will not be consumed in the synthesis reactions.
The oil is a solid at room temperature.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The oil was not previously used so filtration of contaminants is not required.

pageData.question: Which of the following is NOT a potential source of oil for biodiesel synthesis?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Oil from sources such as animal fat, algae, frying oil and plants (such as canola or corn) can be used to synthesize biodiesel.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The first step in the process of biodiesel production is choosing a stock of oil to work from. This can be derived from a variety of sources, including animal fats, or vegetable oils such as corn, canola, or soy. The oil can be produced from algae or can even be recovered from sewage or deep fryers. In general, oil that has been previously used, such as those sourced from deep fryers, has more contaminants that will need to be removed through filtration or other chemical processes, and the oil must be subjected to a drying process to remove excess water. In this investigation, corn oil will be used for the creation of your biodiesel.

The oil can be produced from algae or can even be recovered from sewage or deep fryers. In this investigation, corn oil will be used for the creation of your biodiesel.

pageData.text: Typically, after a batch of biodiesel is created, a bevy of tests are conducted on the sample, testing for the presence of a multitude of molecules and properties. For the purposes of this investigation, pH, density, and the presence of will be tested for. The pH test detects free that have not reacted in the process, these are indicated by a lower pH and typically are the result of a lower quality stock oil, with biodiesel having a typical pH of 7 to 9. Density is a test of biodiesel quality as the density of biodiesel is 0.88 g/mL. The final test is for the presence of unreacted triglycerides, or intermediates, such as a diglyceride. The presence of these indicates an incomplete reaction.

pageData.question: What does the pH test detect?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The pH test detects free fatty acids that have not reacted in the process; these are indicated by a lower pH and typically are the result of a lower quality stock oil.

pageData.question: You have two samples of biodiesel on which you are performing quality tests – a typical sample and a sample synthesized from used frying oil. The sample of typical biodiesel has a pH of 7. The sample of biodiesel synthesized from the used oil is likely to have which of the following pHs?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Biodiesel with a pH lower than that of typical biodiesel (7-9) is usually the result of lower-quality stock oil, such as used frying oil.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The final reaction in biodiesel synthesis yields a methyl ester (biodiesel), a diglyceride, and regenerates the two calcium methoxide catalyst molecules. The process then repeats until each fatty acid is used up and the end products are three methyl esters and a glycerol molecule. Typically, after a batch of biodiesel is created, a bevy of tests are conducted on the sample to test for the presence of a multitude of molecules and properties. For the purposes of this investigation, the biodiesel sample will be tested for pH, density, and the presence of triglycerides. The pH test detects free fatty acids that have not reacted in the process; these are indicated by a lower pH and typically are the result of a lower quality stock oil. Density is a test of biodiesel quality; the density of biodiesel is 0.88 g/mL. The final test is for the presence of unreacted triglycerides, or intermediates, such as diglyceride. The presence of these indicates an incomplete reaction.

pageData.desc: This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. Start Activity 1 by adding calcium hydroxide and methanol to a vial. Next, mix the vial contents. Then allow the contents to rest for 10 minutes. After the vial contents have rested, add to it vegetable oil, and mix the vial contents. Allow the vial contents to rest for 48 hours before continuing to Activity 2. Start Activity 2 by measuring the mass of the 10-mL graduated cylinder and the volume of 1 mL of the biodiesel product. Next, determine the mass of the 1 mL of product. Calculate the density of the product. Next, determine the pH of the product. Finally, perform a test for the intermediate compounds in the product.

Next, determine the mass of the 1 mL of product. Calculate the density of the product. Next, determine the pH of the product. Finally, perform a test for the intermediate compounds in the product.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Activity sections.
Methanol is flammable. Keep this chemical away from any heat or flame sources.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

pageData.text: Calcium hydroxide causes skin irritation.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Calcium hydroxide is a corrosive material and can cause serious eye damage.

pageData.text: Methanol can cause organ damage if ingested. Keep away from food sources.

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Transesterification is the process of exchanging the alcohol group of an ester compound with which of the following functional groups?
An ester compound is derived from which of the following compounds?

Adam has synthesized some biodiesel from soy oil and is testing its pH as part of a series of quality tests. The pH of his biodiesel is 8. Which of the following best describes the quality of his biodiesel?

options.text: Its pH is typical for biodiesel.
Its pH is too high: there is a large portion of free fatty acids in the sample.
Its pH is too low: there is a large portion of free fatty acids in the sample.
Its pH is too high: there is a large portion of intermediates in the sample.
Its pH is too low: there is a large portion of intermediates in the sample.

assestmentData.question: Vivian works at a fast-food restaurant. She has permission from her manager to recycle the used oil from the fryers to create biodiesel, which she uses to fuel a generator at home. Which of the following is most likely the first step Vivian takes to synthesize her biodiesel?

options.text: She filters the oil to remove contaminants.
She creates an emulsion by mixing the oil with water vigorously.
She mixes calcium hydroxide and methanol to produce calcium methoxide.
She tests the pH of the oil.
She mixes calcium methoxide and the oil to produce methyl esters.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best explains why glycerol is a byproduct of biodiesel synthesis?

options.text: The fatty acids of triglycerides react in this process while glycerol does not.
Glycerol is added to this process as a catalyst and is not consumed.
Calcium methoxide breaks down into glycerol and methyl esters during this process.
It is not possible for all the glycerol to react in this process.
Glycerol precipitates out of solution as the pH rises during this process.

assestmentData.question: A glass test tube is provided in your lab kit for this investigation. In the event this item breaks, which of the following best describes the proper clean up and disposal of broken glass?

options.text: Use a broom and dustpan to collect the glass into a secondary container which is disposed of in the household trash.
Use gloved hands to collect the glass into a secondary container which is disposed of in the household recycling.
Use tweezers to collect the glass and dispose of it in the household trash.
Use a vacuum to collect the glass and dispose of it at a chemical disposal facility.
Use oven mitts to collect the glass and dispose of it in the household recycling.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following items in this investigation is a corrosive material?
Which of the following DOES NOT apply to the methanol provided in your lab kit for this investigation?

options.text: It can cause organ damage if ingested.
Keep it away from food sources.
It may be toxic if it contacts skin.

Read procedure thoroughly.
Locate and clean work area.
Gather all needed materials.
In Activity 1, you will synthesize biodiesel from corn oil. This activity needs to be completed at least 48 hours before you intend to start Activity 2.

typeBefore.text: Note: this activity needs to be completed at least 48 hours before you intend to complete Activity 2.

pageData.text: On the balance weigh approximately 0.02 grams of calcium hydroxide into the 3-dram vial.
Measure 8 mL of methanol with a graduated cylinder.
Add methanol to the vial.
Cap vial and shake vigorously. Allow vial to sit for 10 minutes, shaking occasionally.
Carefully open cap away from your face as some pressure may build up.
Measure 1 mL of vegetable oil with a graduated cylinder.
Add vegetable oil to the vial, and cap the vial.
Shake vial vigorously.
Allow the reaction to occur over 48 hours. Shake the vial occasionally to allow the solid calcium methoxide to react with the <button className='glossary-text'>triglycerides</button>.
In Activity 2, you will test the quality of the biodiesel synthesized in Activity 1.
Weigh an empty 10-mL graduated cylinder and record the mass in Data Table 1.
Using a pipet, extract some biodiesel from the vial. The biodiesel should be the top liquid layer.
Dispense ~1 mL of biodiesel into the graduated cylinder. Record the exact volume in Data Table 1.
Weigh the graduated cylinder with biodiesel and record the mass in Data Table 1.

Calculate the mass of the biodiesel.
mass biodiesel = mass of graduated cylinder w/biodiesel—mass of graduated cylinder

Calculate the density of the biodiesel.
density = mass/volume
Take a strip of pH paper and dip it in the biodiesel.
Record the pH in Data Table 1.
Dispense ~1 mL of biodiesel into a glass test tube.
Measure 7 mL of methanol and add it to the test tube.
With a gloved hand, place your thumb over the mouth of the test tube and shake vigorously.
Place the test tube in the test tube rack and allow it to sit for 10 minutes.
Record whether an insoluble layer forms. This layer contains unreacted <button className='glossary-text'>triglycerides</button> or intermediates.

text: Dispose of solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment and return the materials to your equipment kit.

data.title: Catalyst
data.content: Speed up chemical reactions by lowering the activation energy required for the reaction

data.title: Ester
data.content: Typically represented as RCOOR1 where each R represents a carbon chain, the carbon has one oxygen bound to it with a double bond, one oxygen bound with a single bond, and a carbon from the carbon chain

data.title: Fatty acid
data.content: Fats, oils, and waxes, carbon chains containing a methyl group at one end and a carboxyl group at the other, can be saturated or unsaturated

data.title: Transesterification
data.content: Is the process of exchanging an organic ester group with an alcohol group between two molecules

data.title: Triglyceride
data.content: Contain three fatty acid chains bonded to a glycerol molecule (a sugar alcohol)
